title: Enable DND
content:
This topic describes how to enable the Design and Deploy (DND) capability for an existing tenant. 

You need to assign a Cloud Management license to the tenant to access the Design and Deploy functionality. 
For step-by-step instructions on how to enable DND for a tenant and an example use case of DND aggregated offerings, see Cloud Management use case - Design and Deploy.

Prerequisites

Before you proceed, meet the following prerequisites.

  • Make sure the DND capability has been installed in the suite. To see if DND is installed, run the kubectl get pods --all-namespaces | grep dnd command to see if all the DND pods are running and run the kubectl get job --all-namespaces | grep dnd command to make sure all DND job resources have a Complete status. If DND isn't yet installed, you need to add the DND capability to your existing installation. Note that in an on-premises environment, you must modify the pg_hba.conf file of the external PostgreSQL database as required. 
  • Make sure the Operations Orchestration(OO) Containerized capability is installed and enabled. For more information, see Install OO Containerized on-premises, Install OO Containerized on AWS, Install OO Containerized on Azure and Enable OO Containerized in Suite Administration.
  • Make sure that the tenant for which you want to enable DND has a Cloud Management license assigned, has a backend type of SMAX, and is in Active status. 

Configure DND-OO integration

Role required: Suite Administrator

To facilitate communication between DND and OO, you must Import the OO server certificate into DND.

Import OO server certificate into DND

Prerequisite:

Make sure the node where you will download the OO server certificate has the OpenSSL package installed.

To import the OO server certificate into DND:

  1. Run the following command to download the OO server certificate. Replace the <OO_HOST> and <OO_PORT> with the OO server hostname and port. 
    echo -n | openssl s_client -connect "<OO_HOST>:<OO_PORT>" </dev/null 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 > "/tmp/oo.crt
  2. Copy the downloaded OO server certificate from /tmp/oo.crt to <config-volume>/certificate/cmp/source/oo.crt and <config-volume>/certificate/dnd/source/oo.crt.
  3. (Optional) If you have a load balancer certificate, then copy it to <config-volume>/certificate/cmp/source/lb.crt and <config-volume>/certificate/dnd/source/lb.crt.
  4. Restart the platform pod.

Restart pods

 Replace the placeholder <ESM_NAMESPACE> with the unique namespace of the suite deployment and run the following commands to restart the pods:

ns=<ESM_NAMESPACE>
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-xruntime-platform
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-xruntime-platform-offline
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-cmp-config-controller
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-content-store-backend
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-content-store-gateway
kubectl rollout restart deployment -n $ns itom-dnd-controller

Import suite CA certificates into OO 

Perform this task if you haven't provided the suite CA certificate during OO Containerized installation.

  1. Log in to the Suite Administration Portal as suite-admin, and download the suite CA certificate from the browser. For details, see Get the suite CA certificate.

  2. Run the following command to get the OO cert folder: 
    OO_CERT_FOLDER=$(echo `find <path-to-oo-base-persistent-volume> -name certs | grep -v data`) && echo $<OO_CERT_FOLDER>
Example of <path-to-oo-base-persistent-volume> is  /var/vols/itom/oo/
  3. Copy the suite CA certificate to the above <OO_CERT_FOLDER> folder. Example: /var/vols/itom/oo/oo_config_vol/certs/ 
  4. Restart all the OO pods by executing the following commands in sequence.

    For embedded Kubernetes deployments:

    /opt/cdf/scripts/cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l DOWN -n <OO_Namespace>
/opt/cdf/scripts/cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l UP -n <OO_Namespace>

    For managed Kubernetes deployments:

    OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts/cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l DOWN -n <OO_Namespace>
OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts/cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l UP -n <OO_Namespace>

After enabling DND, if you're not able to execute OO flows with a "vault secret load failed" error, follow the troubleshooting given in OO Flows fail to execute with the error "vault secret load failed"

Configure DND as the suite admin

When the dnd-deploy-controller pod is running, the suite admin can set up a DND instance for the tenant as follows. 

  1. Log in to Suite Administration as the suite admin: https://<EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST>/bo.
  2. Prepare the following users:
    User Description
    DND admin user

    A user-facing account with login privileges. This user is a full DND and OO administrator.
    DND transport user

    An integration user for the communication from OO and the suite to DND.

    This user has no UI login privileges. It must be a DB user. Do not set an LDAP, SAML, or OAuth user as the integration user.

    You need to select this integration user as a DND transport user in the DND deployment screen.
     
    For the DND account and integrations users, don't set their password with a double-quote ("), forward-slash (/), or backslash (\) as these special characters aren't supported

    An account user's Role field must be Account user and an integration user's Role field must be Integration user. 

    Before the DND deployment, the suite admin must make sure that the passwords of the prepared account user(s) and integration user are already set and all the users are in Active status (the Status field is Active).

    Except for the above users, the system will automatically create a DND reporting user, a non-user-facing account. The table below lists their detailed information.

    User User name Email address Vault role name User password vault key
    DND reporting user dndReportingUser_<tenant_id> <user_name>@dummy.com dnd_app_role_<tenant_id> dnd_reporting_password_secret_key
  3. In Suite Administration, navigate to TENANTS, select the tenant, and click Capability settings > Deploy new capability.
  4. In the pop-up window, on the Pre-check page, select Design and Deploy from the drop-down list, and click Next.
  5. On the Configure and deploy page, select the prepared users as DND admin user and DND transport user and enter their passwords respectively.
  6. Click DEPLOY. 
    Once you click DEPLOY, the added capability can't be removed.
  7. Now the DND deployment Status is In progress. If it becomes Failed, check the related logs in Operation history for details and click REDEPLOY after the issue is resolved.
    For help with troubleshooting this issue, see DND capability deployment fails.
  8. If the tenant deployment continues to be In progress state for more than 4 hours, the deployment will timeout and it will go to a Failed state. 
  9. [Classic deployment only] It will take some time for DND to be deployed successfully. Note that although the operation history logs indicate the DND instance has been deployed successfully, the DND content installation may still be in progress.

    To check the content installation status, log in to the OMT Management Portal (https://<EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST>:5443), click CLUSTER > Dashboard > Workloads > Pods, and then check the status of the DND content installation pod (itom-dnd-content-install-xxx-xxx).

  10. Wait about 1.5 hours until the content installation is completed.
  11. Navigate to Capability settings and toggle the Enable capability on.
  12. Log in to the agent interface as a tenant admin. Go to Administration > People > Groups. Check that the DND admin user and DND transport user are synced to the agent interface. If not, wait for more time and check again. The system automatically synchronizes user data from Suite Administration to the agent interface every two hours. 
  13. After the system has synchronized the above two users to the agent interface, turn on the Enable capability toggle for the tenant in Suite Administration, and click SAVE. 
    The system might take additional time due to the automatic migration of authorization data.
  14. Click CONFIRM in the pop-up window. DND is enabled in the tenant now.
    The suite admin can manage the DND configurations on the Capability settings tab (Suite Administration > TENANTS > select the tenant > Capability settings), including the credentials of the DND admin, and DND transport users. If any of these users reset their passwords after DND deployment, the suite admin needs to update the recorded credentials on the Capability settings tab accordingly. To update a password, simply enter the new password of a specific user and click SAVE. Then click CONFIRM in the pop-up window and the new password will be saved.

Verify the DND deployment as the tenant admin

After the suite admin has enabled DND for the tenant, the tenant admin needs to verify the DND enablement in the agent interface. 

  1. Check that the system has replicated the seeded roles and groups for DND and Content Store and their relationships to the agent interface.  
    Roles

    Groups
  2. Check that the DND admin user is assigned to the following groups: Content Store Tenant Administrators, and DND Administrators. 

After DND is enabled, the Content Management service (Content Store) is deployed automatically and is accessible to existing DND users. 

Configure DND as the tenant admin

The tenant admin needs to perform the following tasks.

Configure tenant application settings

In the agent portal, navigate to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings, and perform the following steps: 

  1. Check that the Enable Service Design and Deployment option is set to On. This option is set to On automatically after the suite admin has installed the DND content.
  2. Check that the Experience mode setting includes the Cloud Management module. This is required for the Design and Deployment Operations menu items to become available for the tenant. For more information about the available modules, see Experience mode.
  3. Turn on the Enable aggregation feature. For more information, see Enable aggregation. 
  4. Create a tenant key chain in the Tenant key chain section. For details, see Tenant key chain. 

Configure authorization for additional DND users

By default, the tenant admin specified in Suite Administration has the privilege to access the DND data and menu items. If you want additional users such as service designers to access the DND data and menu items, you need to configure authorization in Service Management for these users. For details, see Configure authorization for Design and Deploy. 

Configure user role for DND menu visibility

DND users need the CMP Agent user role to access the DND menu items in the agent portal. For details, see Configure user role for menu visibility in Service Management.

Add service providers

Add service providers in the AGGREGATION PROVIDERS view from Administration > Utilities > Providers before the catalog admin can add aggregated offerings. For details, see Create and edit aggregation providers. 

DND application properties

A subset of properties has been moved to the database. For more information on the properties, see DND application properties. In this release, you can update or get the values of the properties from the database by using APIs. For more information on the APIs, see DND APIs to get or update application properties

Import server certificate into DND truststore

Perform the following steps when the product is deployed on Azure using the Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).
  1. Log in to the Service Portal in a browser.
  2. Export the certificate from the browser in the .PEM format. If your browser exports the certificate in .cer format, make sure the file format chosen for export is Base-64 encoded.
  3. Rename the .PEM file by changing the file extension from .PEM to .crt. If the file you have exported in .cer file, do not just rename the file by changing the extension from .cer to .crt. Use a converter to convert the .cer file to .crt file.
  4. Copy the server certificate into the NFS shared folder <global-volume>/certificate/cmp/source.

    Example: /var/vols/itom/dnd/certificate/cmp/source

  5. Run the following commands to restart the DND and Content Store pods: 
    kubectl scale deployment itom-dnd-controller-deployment --replicas=0 -n <namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-dnd-controller-deployment --replicas=1 -n <namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-content-store-backend --replicas=0 -n <namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-content-store-backend --replicas=1 -n <namespace>

Configure DND-UCMDB integration

Native SACM is a solution for the entire Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) process with instant access to the data and embedded graphical widgets for CI topology representation. You can integrate DND with UCMDB using Native SACM to achieve seamless data federation through UCMDB Gateway. For more information on how to configure the integration, see Configure DND-UCMDB integration.

Related topics

  • For information on the scaling of DND, see DND scaling
  • For help with troubleshooting DND deployment failure issues, see DND capability deployment fails
  • After enabling DND, if you're not able to run OO flows with the vault secret load failed error, follow the troubleshooting given in OO Flows fail to execute with the error "vault secret load failed"
